item.title: The Cover-Up: Inside the Plot to Conceal Assad’s Crimes
item.description: Thousands of documents and interviews with Assad-era officials reveal how the regime worked to conceal evidence of its atrocities during the Syrian civil war.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Saad Alnassife
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Russia and Ukraine Are Fighting to Shape Trump’s View of the War
item.description: Off the battlefield, each side is trying to influence President Trump’s perception of the military conflict as they look to negotiate a peace settlement in their favor.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, right, with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Sunday. The two leaders held talks about ending the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Saudis Say Airstrike in Yemen Targeted Arms From U.A.E.
item.description: Saudi-led forces struck an Emirati shipment early Tuesday, worsening tensions between the once-close allies. The Saudis said the shipment had arms for a separatist group, which the Emiratis denied.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Ismaeel Naar
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Damaged military vehicles at the port of Al Mukalla in Yemen, where a Saudi-led coalition struck an arms shipment on Tuesday.

item.title: Protests Over Iran’s Currency Crash and Inflation Spread to Universities
item.description: Iranian leaders face pressure over a currency collapse and threats of possible military strikes from Israel and the United States over Tehran’s nuclear activities.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Sanam Mahoozi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by Iranian state media shows closed shops after protests in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: PostNord, Denmark’s Main Postal Carrier, Ends Letter Delivery
item.description: PostNord, the country’s longtime service, is delivering its last letters. Few Danes send snail mail anymore, but some are mourning the end of an era.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Kristian Tuxen Ladegaard Berg/NurPhoto, via Reuters
item.media:description: Two mailboxes in front of the Marble Church in Copenhagen. There has been a steep decline in the use of Denmark’s postal service for sending letters.

item.title: Spanish Woman Scorned, Then Loved, for Botched Fresco Restoration Dies at 94
item.description: Cecilia Giménez’s repainting of an image of Jesus in 2012 was widely mocked online. But tourists flocked to see her work, reviving her struggling hometown.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cecilia Giménez, an amateur painter, at her home in Borja, Spain, in 2014.

item.title: China Fires Rockets Near Taiwan in Display of Military Power
item.description: China’s military also sent warships and aircraft during a second day of exercises designed to show its ability to claim the democratic island.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Adek Berry/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Chinese military fired a rocket on Tuesday from Pingtan, an island in the eastern province of Fujian that is China’s closest point to Taiwan.

item.title: Yonaguni, the Japanese Island on the Front Lines of China’s Feud with Japan
item.description: Yonaguni, a tiny Japanese island near Taiwan, is getting soldiers, radar and missiles. As China’s dispute with Tokyo escalates, some residents are worried.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, Hisako Ueno and Ko Sasaki
item.media:description: Yonaguni, a Japanese military outpost about 70 miles east of Taiwan, sits along the so-called “first island chain,” a strategic arc of islands used to hem in Chinese naval expansion.

item.title: Did Starmer Impose a Curfew in the U.K.? No, It’s a Fake TikTok Video.
item.description: A.I. has made it easy to put words in people’s mouths, and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain has become a favorite target. The motive, experts say, is not political but financial.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: International Panel on the Information Environment
item.media:credit: Ben Stansall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer leaving 10 Downing Street this month. He has been the subject of many fake videos made with the help of A.I. technology.

item.title: In Lagos, December Is Time to Get Down and ‘Detty’
item.description: Detty December means a month of “back to back to back” partying in Nigeria’s megacity, both for locals and visiting members of the diaspora. Bring your stamina, dancing shoes and wads of cash.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Taiwo Aina
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times

item.title: Eurostar Trains Face Day of Delays After Power Failure
item.description: The high-speed service between Britain and continental Europe was paralyzed during one of the busiest travel weeks of the year because of a power outage in the Channel Tunnel.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross, Amelia Nierenberg and Ana Castelain
item.media:credit: Maja Smiejkowska/Reuters
item.media:description: Passengers at London St. Pancras International station on Tuesday, after Eurostar canceled trains between London and continental Europe.

item.title: George Clooney Is French Now
item.description: The actor and his wife, Amal Clooney, were granted French citizenship. He has spoken fondly of raising their children in a farmhouse they bought in Provence.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: France has granted citizenship to George Clooney and his wife, Amal Clooney.

item.title: Grim Evidence of Trump’s Boat Strikes Washes Ashore on a Colombian Peninsula
item.description: First came the scorched boat. Then the mangled bodies. Then the packets with traces of marijuana. Now, fishermen fear the ocean that feeds them.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Simón Posada, Christiaan Triebert and Federico Rios
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russia Threatens to Toughen Its Stance on Ending the War in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow said a Ukrainian drone attack targeted a residence of President Vladimir V. Putin, which Ukraine denied, accusing the Kremlin of fabricating an excuse not to make peace.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Mikhail Metzel/Sputnik
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with military officers in Moscow on Monday, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Brigitte Bardot’s Legacy of Racist Rhetoric
item.description: The actress, who died this week at 91, was an icon of 1960s cinema. She was also a hero to the French far right.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Pascal Pavani/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brigitte Bardot, center, appeared in court in 1997 on charges of inciting racial hatred.

item.title: Slow Flood Recovery Stirs Anger in Far-Flung Corner of Indonesia
item.description: Protests have erupted in Aceh Province on the northern tip of Sumatra island, where anger and frustration are mounting over what many see as inadequate relief efforts by a distracted government.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti

item.title: 6 Takeaways on the Unwinding U.S.-Ukraine Alliance
item.description: A Times investigation reveals the inside story of the Trump administration’s chaotic push for a peace deal and its erratic role in the war.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Trump at Mar-a-Lago on Sunday.

item.title: Overlooked Stories
item.description: We look at some of our best stories of 2025 that you might have missed in the year’s avalanche of news.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Evgenia Arbugaeva for The New York Times

item.title: Gaza Aid Groups Face Suspensions Under New Israeli Rules
item.description: The organizations, including Doctors Without Borders, have resisted providing Israel with detailed information about their workers.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians climbed onto a truck carrying aid near Gaza City in August.

item.title: The C.I.A. Strike on Venezuela: What to Know
item.description: The drone attack, said to be on a dock where drugs were being prepared for loading on boats, represented a further escalation of the Trump administration’s campaign against Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Reuters
item.media:description: An American MQ-9 Reaper drone at an airfield in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, last week. The C.I.A. used a drone to target a suspected drug-trafficking site in Venezuela.

item.title: Crew Paints Russian Flag on Oil Tanker Pursued by the U.S. Coast Guard
item.description: The U.S. military tried to intercept the Bella 1 last week in the Caribbean Sea as it headed to Venezuela to pick up oil.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Nicholas Nehamas and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How the Assad Regime Covered Up Its Crimes: Key Takeaways
item.description: We documented how the dictator Bashar al-Assad and his henchmen conspired to hide evidence of torture and deaths of detainees during Syria’s long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members looked for signs of missing relatives as they foraged through papers in the Sednaya prison days after the fall of President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: K-Pop Group NewJeans Faces New Uncertainty After Member Is Dropped
item.description: The band’s label said it had dropped one of the girl group’s five members. NewJeans’s legal battle has drawn public scrutiny of the K-pop industry.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The K-pop group NewJeans in Seoul last year.

item.title: The ‘Trump Effect’ on Global Elections
item.description: President Trump has become a common theme in races around the world. Our Canada bureau chief, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, gives a rundown of some of the results.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Melanie Bencosme, Karen Hanley, Laura Salaberry and James Surdam

item.title: The Trends, Colors and Styles That Dominated Wardrobes in 2025
item.description: These were some of the common threads connecting outfits worn by different people at different times in different places this year.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha

item.title: Cheap Solar Is Transforming Lives and Economies Across Africa
item.description: Chinese panels are now so affordable that businesses and families are snapping them up, slashing their bills and challenging utilities.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh’s First Female Prime Minister, Dies
item.description: In office for three terms, she traded the country’s leadership with Sheikh Hasina, the head of another political dynasty, over decades. She was believed to be 80.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat, Mujib Mashal and Alan Cowell
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Khaled Hasan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khaleda Zia in 2014.

item.title: Trump and Netanyahu Praise Each Other After Meeting, Despite Differences Over Gaza
item.description: The American and Israeli leaders showed few signs of disagreement after meeting in Florida, giving no public indication of their growing strains over Gaza, Syria and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Idris Elba is Knighted as Part of King Charles’s New Year Honors List
item.description: The actors were among more than 1,000 people honored by King Charles III in an annual tradition celebrating professional excellence and community service.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Alexander Hassenstein/Getty Images
item.media:description: England’s national women’s team lifts the trophy after defeating Spain to win the European women’s soccer championship, in July in Switzerland.

item.title: Gone in 2025: A Yearlong Procession of Giants
item.description: Marquee names all, they found international fame in the arts, politics, the sciences and beyond.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from left: Rob Reiner, Val Kilmer, Diane Keaton, David Lynch, Robert Redford, Pope Francis and Gene Hackman.

item.title: Israel Strips U.N. Agency for Palestinian Refugees of Diplomatic Immunity
item.description: The legislation was the latest blow to the agency, known as UNRWA. Israel has accused it of being extensively infiltrated by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Johnatan Reiss
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flour being distributed in Gaza City from a center run by UNRWA, in April.

item.title: The Year in Pictures
item.description: We look back on 2025 with some of the best New York Times photographs.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Pledges $2 Billion for U.N. Aid but Trump Administration Tells Agencies to ‘Adapt, Shrink, or Die’
item.description: The announcement will likely keep the United States as the biggest international aid donor next year, even as the Trump administration slashes funding for foreign assistance programs.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bags of rations being unloaded at a World Food Program distribution point last year at a temporary camp for refugees from Sudan in Adre, Chad.

item.title: Trump, Pressing Ahead on Ukraine-Russia Talks, Confronts Difficult Realities
item.description: The U.S.-led negotiations have made some progress, but still face fundamental challenges, including over security guarantees to counter future Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with a Ukrainian antiaircraft defense unit monitoring the sky for Russian drones in the Donetsk region last week.

item.title: Iran’s Currency Collapse Pushes Protesters to the Streets
item.description: High inflation and a currency collapse have squeezed Iranians’ budgets, challenging the country’s leaders.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Sanam Mahoozi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Fars News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Iranian state media shows a protest in Tehran on Monday, a day after Iran’s currency hit a new low against the U.S. dollar.

item.title: ISIS Militants Kill 3 Police Officers in Turkey
item.description: A raid on a suspected safe house for the terrorist group Islamic State set off a clash that killed the police officers as well as six Turkish militants.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Umit Bektas/Reuters
item.media:description: A raid on a suspected Islamic State safe house in northwestern Turkey on Monday left nine people dead.

item.title: For Zelensky, Just Keeping Trump Talking About Ukraine Peace Deal Counts as a Win
item.description: Though discussions produced little tangible progress, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at least avoided the type of setbacks that have blighted earlier meetings.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier monitoring the sky for Russian drones in the Donetsk region this past week. Russia has stuck firmly to its view that Ukraine must relinquish the entire region.

item.title: Four Takeaways From the New York Times Profile of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: The congresswoman discussed her break with President Trump and her journey from MAGA zealot to political isolation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Philip Montgomery for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greene and her staff at the Capitol complex in mid-December, when she cast her final vote on her last day working in Washington.

item.title: Experts Question Denmark’s Vaccine Program as a Model for the U.S.
item.description: The United States is expected to adopt the vaccine schedule used by Denmark, a much smaller country with universal health care.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denmark, a country of six million, has universal health care, so Danes can get treated more easily for diseases than Americans and often seek medical help earlier.

item.title: Claire Brosseau Wants to Die. Will Canada Let Her?
item.description: Ms. Brosseau says mental illness has made her life unbearable. She wants a medically assisted death. Even her psychiatrists are split over whether she should have one.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Chloë Ellingson
item.media:credit: Chloë Ellingson for The New York Times

item.title: China Mobilizes Forces Near Taiwan for Live-Fire Drill
item.description: The exercises ended months of relative calm across the Taiwan Strait, and came after the Trump administration announced plans for arms sales to the island.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Cheng Yu-Chen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Taiwan Air Force Mirage 2000 fighter jet taking off from Hsinchu Air Base in Hsinchu, Taiwan on Monday. China on Monday launched its first major military exercises around Taiwan since April.

item.title: The World Wants More Ube. Philippine Farmers Are Struggling to Keep Up.
item.description: Soaring demand and extreme weather worsened by climate change have wiped out harvests of the popular purple yam.
item.dc:creator: Rambo Talabong and Jes Aznar

item.title: With Critical Decisions Ahead, Netanyahu Faces Mounting Pressure
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has a series of vexing choices to make in the year ahead on issues including Gaza, conscription and a judicial overhaul, with elections looming.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Jerusalem in October.

item.title: Trump Says the U.S. Struck a ‘Big Facility’ in Campaign Against Venezuela
item.description: The administration provided no details of what the president said was an attack last week linked to U.S. efforts to disrupt drug trafficking from Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Such an attack would be the first on land since President Trump began his military campaign against Venezuela.

item.title: Mexico Train Derailment Kills 13 People
item.description: The train was carrying around 250 passengers and crew members on a cross-country route linking the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico. Nearly 100 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Rusvel Rasgado/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mexican emergency workers rescuing passengers from a train that derailed in the southern state of Oaxaca on Sunday.

item.title: Trump and Zelensky Meet to Iron Out Peace Plan, but Deal Remains Elusive
item.description: The U.S. president said after a meeting at Mar-a-Lago that a deal was “maybe very close.” But a joint U.S.-Ukraine proposal appeared unfinished, as Russia rejected several ideas.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump hosted President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at Mar-a-Lago on Sunday. “In a few weeks, we’ll know one way or another,” Mr. Trump said of a peace deal.

item.title: The Best of Culture
item.description: Our culture and lifestyle editor looks back at the year’s top pop culture moments.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Syrian Protests Over Lack of Security Leave 2 Dead
item.description: Days after a bombing at a mosque in a predominantly Alawite area, members of the religious minority in Syria demonstrated for better protections.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Karam Al-Masri/Reuters
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian security forces standing guard during a protest by people from the Alawite religious minority in Latakia, Syria, on Sunday.

item.title: Zelensky to Meet With Trump at Mar-a-Lago About Plan to End War With Russia
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine brings a revised 20-point peace proposal, as well as doubts about whether Russia is serious about pursuing peace.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times & Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Zero Hour for the Middle East
item.description: After more than a decade of wars, from Syria to Gaza, the Middle East is exhausted by conflict. Is it ready to find another way?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen, David Guttenfelder, Saher Alghorra, Daniel Berehulak and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: For more than a decade, war has ravaged the Middle East.

item.title: Twins’ Peaks: The Gilbertson Brothers Want to Rewrite Your Country’s Map
item.description: Two brothers, both mechanical engineers, are climbing many of the world’s tall peaks to prove they have been measured incorrectly.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles

item.title: What to Know About Colombia’s Role in the Global Drug Trade Amid Trump’s Feud With Petro
item.description: President Gustavo Petro is locked in a war of words with President Trump over Colombia’s major role in the global drug trade. The issue is complicated.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Ramón Campos Iriarte for The New York Times

item.title: How Cameroon Fought to Save Its Malaria Program After the U.S. Cut Critical Funding
item.description: When the Trump administration slashed foreign aid, it gutted a program that had reduced malaria deaths world wide. In northern Cameroon, health workers tried to protect children in one last rainy season.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Arlette Bashizi
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times

item.title: The Lure of a Rising Asian Metropolis? No Traffic.
item.description: Indonesia is building a new, green city in the jungle. Its future is far from certain, but new residents like living there.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:description: The wings statue at Kusuma Bangsa Park in Nusantara, with the presidential palace and government ministry buildings in the background, at Penajam North Paser Regency in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, in November.

item.title: Guinea Goes to Polls as Ruling Junta Seeks Legitimacy
item.description: Whoever wins faces the daunting task of feeding the West African country’s poor and navigating the interests of global powers seeking critical minerals, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Patrick Meinhardt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A supporter dressed as Mamady Doumbouya traveling with armed escorts in Conakry, Guinea, on Thursday.

item.title: Families Demand Answers a Year After Deadliest Plane Crash in South Korea
item.description: Many details of the Jeju Air disaster that killed 179 people remain unclear despite multiple investigations by officials and protests by the victims’ families.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The wreckage of Jeju Air Flight 2216 late last year at the Muan International Airport in Muan, South Korea.

item.title: In Myanmar’s Election, ‘Voting Out of Fear, Not Hope’
item.description: The voting for Parliament is almost sure to favor the ruling military junta, which is stage-managing the polls. Still, some see them as the most pragmatic way to try to improve conditions.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Military officers and family members lining up to vote in a military zone in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, on Sunday.
